provenance.name: Fitzwilliam Museum
provenance.note: Probably acquired by Blake's wife, Catherine, upon his death in 1827; Frederick Tatham, probably upon Mrs. Blake's death in 1831; sold from Tatham's collection, Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, lot 188 (£1.11s. to the dealer H. Palser); William Linnell, the son of Blake's friend and patron John Linnell, by 1876; William Linnell's son-in-law T. H. Riches, probably by 1906; bequeathed by Riches to the Fitzwilliam Museum in 1936.

desc.objtitle: The House of Death (Fitzwilliam Museum), Object 1 (Butlin 322)

objnote.p: "The House of Death" is based on Adam's vision of "a Lazar-house" in John Milton's *Paradise Lost*, Book 11, lines 477-93. "Triumphant Death" hovers above the stricken, his "Dart[s]" descending below each hand. The curved form extending between his hands seems poised ambiguously between a bow and a scroll. The figure far right, with a dagger in his left hand, may be a personification of Milton's "despair" who "tended the sick."
The back of the frame is inscribed by William Linnell, "This drawing by Wm Blake does not belong to the series of Mr J. Linnell Senr. but was bought by me of a dealer in London. William Linnell."

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the upper center of the design hovers a god-like figure, probably personified Death, in accord with the passage illustrated from Milton's Paradise Lost. His eyes are closed and he has an unusually long, flowing beard. He hovers above or within a cloud. Beneath his raised arms and hands appears a bow-shaped scroll with a coiled right end. Three figures lie in pain on a heavy woven mat below Death. There may be the chest (?) of a fourth figure lying on the mat, just beyond and to the left of the third figure. We see the head and upper body of another figure proped up behind those lying on the mat. All four or five are probably dying. A figure along the right margin of the design stands, or walks towards the left, with his head hanging low, while holding a dagger in his left hand. He may be a personification of "despair" in Milton's text. In the middle distance, right side of the cloud, is a hunched-over figure whose hands clasp either side of his head. Reddish hues around this figure and in the cloud hint at fire or a sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: An old man with long, spiky hair and an unusually long, flowing beard hovers in the upper center of, or is hovering just above, a cloud. We see only his arms, hands, head, enormous beard, and possibly something of his gown or long, flowing shirt between the lower locks of his beard. This gown or shirt clearly covers his arms. His eyes are closed, or possibly sealed to indicate blindness, and his arms are raised horizontally with his palms facing down. A bow-like scroll extends between his hands; he may be holding it. The downward-pointing thumbs of both hands are carefully delineated. This god-like figure is probably a personification of Death, in accord with the passage illustrated in Milton's Paradise Lost.

A cloud appears below the top center figure, possibly supporting him. It, or another cloud, appears on both sides of his head and extends to the margin of the design on the right. Reddish hues on the cloud and surrounding the figure's head right of the cloud hint at fire or a sunrise or sunset.
A bow-like scroll with a coiled right end extends between the hands of the top center figure.

A nude, bald, and muscular male, just within the right margin of the design, stands (or walks towards the left) with his head bowed down. His left eye stares blankly downward. His skin is dark and slightly greenish. He holds a dagger in his left hand with his forefinger along the blade. His left arm is at his side. The figure’s left ear is prominent. He probably personifies "despair" in the passage illustrated in Milton's *Paradise Lost*.

The muscular male lying on the mat, closest to the viewer, is nude, with his genital area exposed but not delineated in detail. While his head and upper body are bent towards the mat, the bottom half of his body (hips and below) faces the viewer; this is particularly true of the right leg, which lies in front of the left leg, crossing the left leg at the ankle. The left arm is sharply bent upwards over his left shoulder with the fingers of his left hand spread apart. His right arm is not pictured, but is presumably under his body. His face, as well as his twisted posture and rigid fingers, express despair and pain. He has long hair and his mouth is slightly open; perhaps we see some of his teeth or a bit of his tongue. He is probably diseased and dying.

The second man from the front on the mat is nude and lies supine. His chest is arched upward. His tensed body, backward bent head, and slightly opened mouth (with a tooth visible?) suggest that he is in pain. His arms are not pictured. The back of his head with long hair lies on top of the mat. His face is facing to the left, although upside down. His eyes may be rolled back in his head, or perhaps raised, and he is probably diseased and dying.

Along with the two front-most figures, the third nude male from the viewer on the mat lies on his right side and faces the viewer. His eyes are turned upwards and his mouth is opened wide, with teeth and tongue visible; he may be howling in pain. His facial expression suggests a mixture of despair and pain. His hair is between short and long; he may be bearded. His left knee is drawn up towards his chest; is left leg may be crossed over his right leg. Both feet, but particularly the left, are prominent. He is probably diseased and dying, like his companions on the mat.

There may be a fourth figure lying on the mat, between the left margin and the head of the third figure from the front. We see only his bare chest (?), a bit arched and rigid, or his back, and possibly something of his upper arm.

Beneath the three men is a large braided or rope-like straw(?) mat or carpet that spans the entire bottom margin of the design. Perhaps we see a narrow strip of uncovered floor along the bottom margin of the design, with a long shadow extending from the right.
In the lower left corner, the third figure from the front appears to rest his head on a small mound or pillow, not woven like the mat.

A bald male in the middle distance just inside the left margin (fourth or fifth figure from the front) is visible, nude, from the stomach up. He looks up in right profile towards Death with his mouth open, as if in terror. His right ear is prominent. He is probably half-sitting, half-lying, with his upper body propped up on his arms. His right shoulder cradles his head, which is bent severely backwards. He is probably diseased and dying.

In the middle distance right of the cloud is a (male?) figure who faces the viewer and bows his head to the ground. We see only the top of his head, hands, and possibly his back. Both of the figure's hands are raised, palms vertical, parallel to the sides of his head. His hair appears to be short; his posture suggests despair.
The background of the design (behind the figures on the left and right) is dark, suggesting an ominous atmosphere.
